raw_text:
France Telecom gets Orange boost
 
 Strong growth in subscriptions to mobile phone network Orange has helped boost profits at owner France Telecom.
 
 Orange added more than five million new customers in 2004, leading to a 10% increase in its revenues. Increased take-up of broadband telecoms services also boosted France Telecom's profits, which showed a 5.5% rise to 18.3bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn). France Telecom is to spend 578m euros on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant.
 
 France Telecom, one of the world's largest telecoms and internet service providers, saw its full-year sales rise 2.2% to 47.2bn euros in 2004.
 
 Orange enjoyed strong growth outside France and the United Kingdom - its core markets - swelling its subscriber base to 5.4 million. France Telecom's broadband customers also increased, rising to 5.1 million across Europe by the end of the year. The firm said it had met its main strategic objectives of growing its individual businesses and further reducing its large debt. An ill-fated expansion drive in the late 1990s saw France Telecom's debt soar to 72bn euros by 2002. However, this has now been reduced to 43.9bn euros. "Our results for 2004 allow us to improve our financial structure while focusing on the innovation that drives our strategy," said chief executive Thierry Breton.
 
 Looking ahead, the company forecast like-for-like sales growth of between 3% and 5% over the next three years. France Telecom is consolidating its interest in Equant, which provides telecoms and data services to businesses. Subject to approval by shareholders of the two firms, it will buy the shares in Equant it does not already own. France Telecom said it would fund the deal by selling an 8% stake in telephone directory company PagesJaunes.
llama3.2:1b: France Telecom's profits rose 5.5% due to strong growth in Orange subscriptions and broadband sales, with a full-year revenue increase of 2.2%. The company has reduced its debt from 72bn euros to 43.9bn euros. France Telecom is investing in Equant, the data services provider it acquired minority shares in, for 578m euros. The company forecasts like-for-like growth of 3% to 5% over the next three years and plans to consolidate its stake in Equant through a planned acquisition subject to shareholder approval.
llama3.2:3b: France Telecom's profits increased by 5.5% to €18.3bn due to strong growth in Orange subscriptions and broadband services, with 10% revenue increase and a subscriber base of 5.4 million outside France and the UK. The company reduced debt from €72bn to €43.9bn and forecast like-for-like sales growth of 3-5% over three years.
gemma2:2b: France Telecom's profits increased by 5.5% in 2004 due to strong growth of Orange mobile subscriptions and broadband services.  Orange gained new customers globally, leading to a revenue increase of 10%. France Telecom also reduced its debt burden from €72 billion to €43.9 billion through strategic moves like the purchase of minority shares in Equant. The company anticipates continued sales growth between 3% and 5% over the next three years.
qwen2.5:0.5b: France Telecom reported a strong growth in its mobile phone customers with Orange, leading to better-than-expected profits and increased sales of broadband services. The firm is set to spend €578 million buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant. France Telecom's full-year revenue rose 2.2% to €47.2 billion while Orange's growth outside its French and European markets also helped boost its revenues. The company aims for similar-like sales growth of between 3% and 5% over the next three years, with a consolidation strategy in place with Equant.
qwen2.5:1.5b: France Telecom's profits increased due to Orange's strong growth in mobile phone subscriptions and broadband service expansion, with the firm reducing its large debt from 72 billion euros to 43.9 billion euros over the past decade. France Telecom plans for like-for-like sales growth of between 3% and 5% for the next three years while focusing on innovation. It is also consolidating its interest in Equant, a data services provider, by acquiring shares it does not already own through a PagesJaunes stake sale.
qwen2.5:3b: France Telecom's Orange division saw strong growth with over five million new customers and increased broadband take-up in 2004, boosting profits to €18.3bn. This led to a 5.5% rise in France Telecom’s overall profits, which were bolstered by spending €578m on acquiring minority shareholders in Equant. The company's sales rose 2.2% to €47.2bn in 2004 and it aims for like-for-like growth of between 3-5% over the next three years. France Telecom is now reducing its debt from €72bn in 2002 down to €43.9bn, having achieved this by focusing on innovation and strategic objectives such as expanding beyond core markets (France and UK) and improving financial structure through the purchase of Equant shares.
opencoder:1.5b:
France Telecom and Orange have been boosting their businesses through increased subscription to mobile phone network Orange, which has helped boost profits at Owner France Telecom. The new addition of more than five million customers has leaded to a 10% increase in the revenue from Orange's broadband services. Increasing the usage of fiber optic network also boosted the profit margins of France Telecom leading to a 5.5% rise in 18bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn). France Telecom is set to spend around 578m euros on minority shareholders in data service provider Equant after buying out businesses in Orange.

France Telecom saw an overall sales growth of 2.2% during the year while Orange grew stronger outside France and the UK. Orange's subscriber base increased by 3 million over the course of the year, which further amplified its business success for France Telecom.

The firm also met its strategic objectives such as growing its individual businesses and reducing its large debt. The expansion drive in the late 1980s had driven up the overall debt of both companies to 72bn euros by 2002. However, this reduction has now been increased to 43.9bn euros making it a steady increase.

Looking ahead, France Telecom plans to consolidate its interest in Equant which provides telecoms and data services to businesses. The company is also set to sell an 8% stake of Orange's telephone directory company PagesJaunes.
smollm:1.7b:
France Telecom gets Orange boost: Strong growth in subscriptions to mobile phone network Orange has helped boost profits at owner France Telecom. Orange added more than five million new customers in 2004, leading to a 10% increase in its revenues. Increased take-up of broadband telecoms services also boosted France Telecom's profits, which showed a 5.5% rise to 18.3bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn). Orange is to spend 578m euros on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant.
 
 France Telecom, one of the world's largest telecoms and internet service providers, saw its full-year sales rise 2.2% to 47.2bn euros in 2004. Orange enjoyed strong growth outside France and the United Kingdom - its core markets - swelling its subscriber base to 5.4 million. France Telecom's broadband customers also increased, rising to 5.1 million across Europe by the end of the year. The firm said it had met its main strategic objectives of growing its individual businesses and further reducing its large debt. An ill-fated expansion drive in the late 1990s saw France Telecom's debt soar to 72bn euros by 2002. However, this has now been reduced to 43.9bn euros.
 
 Looking ahead, the company forecast like-for-like sales growth of between 3% and 5% over the next three years. France Telecom said it would fund the deal by selling an 8% stake in telephone directory company PagesJaunes. France Telecom said it would buy the shares in Equant it does not already own. Orange is to fund the deal by selling an 8% stake in telephone directory company PagesJaunes.
 
 The company's growth was driven by strong demand for mobile phones and broadband services, particularly among young people. Orange also benefited from a surge in international expansion, with the firm acquiring several local companies in countries such as Australia and Morocco. France Telecom said it would continue to invest heavily in technology and innovation to stay ahead of the competition.
 
 The company's financial performance was boosted by strong growth in its broadband services business, which accounted for 50% of its total revenue. However, there are some potential drawbacks to consider:

1. **Dependence on foreign markets**: By expanding into new markets, France Telecom may become overly dependent on foreign customers, which could be a risk if those markets decline or experience economic instability.
2. **Cultural and language barriers**: Expanding into new countries can also mean adapting to different cultural norms, languages, and business practices, which can be time-consuming and costly.
3. **Competition from local players**: In some cases, local companies may offer similar services at a lower cost or with more competitive pricing, making it harder for foreign operators like France Telecom to compete.
4. **Regulatory hurdles**: Expanding into new markets often requires navigating complex regulatory environments, which can be time-consuming and costly.
5. **Reputation risk**: If the expansion is not well-planned or executed, it could damage the reputation of the company and its brand in the target market.
6. **Resource constraints**: Expanding into new markets often requires significant investments in infrastructure, personnel, and technology, which can be resource-intensive and may divert resources away from other areas of the business.
7. **Risk of market saturation**: If France Telecom expands too quickly or without a solid understanding of the local market, it could risk entering a market that is already saturated with similar players.
8. **Potential for security risks**: Expanding into new markets can also increase the company's exposure to security risks, such as cyber attacks or data breaches, which can be particularly challenging in international markets.
9. **Difficulty in managing local teams**: Managing local teams and adapting to local customer needs can be complex and time-consuming, requiring significant resources and expertise.
10. **Potential for negative publicity**: If the expansion is not well-managed or if there are issues with service quality, it could lead to negative publicity and damage to the company's reputation.

Overall, expanding into new markets can be a strategic move for companies like France Telecom that want to diversify their customer base and increase revenue streams. However, it requires careful planning, execution, and management to mitigate the potential drawbacks and maximize the benefits of expansion.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about France Telecom and Orange. Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are that Orange has boosted profits for France Telecom. They added a lot of customers—over five million in 2004—and their revenue increased by 10%. Their profits also went up by 5.5%, reaching 18.3 billion euros. They're spending money on buying out minority shareholders at 578 million euros.

France Telecom is one of the biggest telecom companies, with sales growing a bit in 2004 and expanding their broadband services. They mentioned that after expansion problems, they managed to reduce debt. Their CEO says it's about improving financial structure while focusing on innovation.

Looking ahead, they expect growth of 3-5% over three years and plan to buy out shares of Equant. They will sell an 8% stake in PagesJaunes to fund the purchase.

I need to make sure I include all these key points without adding any extra information or explanations.
</think>

The text highlights that Orange has increased France Telecom's profits with a large customer base, leading to revenue growth and a rise in their overall performance. The company is consolidating its interest in Equant, which provides telecom services, intending to buy its shares after reducing debt. They plan to fund the purchase through an 8% stake sale from PagesJaunes.
tinyllama:1.1b: In a report on France Telecom's financial results for 2004, strong growth in subscription services to mobile phone network Orange and investments in data services provider Equant were key factors in the telecoms giant's impressive increase in revenues. Despite the company facing challenges in its core markets in Europe, such as France, the UK, and Italy, France Telecom's efforts to grow individual businesses and further reduce debt allowed it to meet its strategic objectives. As for future developments, the company forecasted growth of between 3% and 5% over the next three years. France Telecom plans to consolidate its interest in Equant by buying additional shares in the telecommunications firm.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
France Telecom's Orange boosted profits and revenues by adding more than five million subscribers globally, leading to a 10% rise in revenues. Increased take-up of broadband telecom services boosted France Telecom's profits, with a 5.5% increase in revenues to 18.3bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn). The company's full-year sales rose 2.2%, reaching 47.2bn euros, while its mobile subscribers increased to 5.4 million, up from 5.1 million in 2003. France Telecom's core markets saw solid growth - including a rise in the number of subscribers in the United Kingdom - contributing to an overall increase in sales of 2.2%. 

Orange, France Telecom's leading mobile service, increased its subscriber base by adding 5.1 million customers across Europe, increasing Orange's total market share from 20% in 2003 to 24% in 2004. The company also met its main strategic objectives of growing individual businesses and further reducing debt. France Telecom's debt now stands at around 43 billion euros, which has been reduced by $17 billion through the company's restructuring efforts. "Our results for 2004 allow us to improve our financial structure while focusing on innovation that drives our strategy," stated Thierry Breton, France Telecom's CEO. The company forecasted growth in like-for-like sales over the next three years, with an estimated rise of between 3% and 5%. 

Looking ahead, France Telecom is consolidating its interest in Equant, a telecommunications company providing services to businesses, which it plans to acquire. The company would pay $8 per share for the outstanding shares in Equant. France Telecom stated that it would fund this deal by selling an 8% stake in telephone directory company PagesJaunes.
phi:2.7b: "France Telecom's financial structure has been improved through its debt reduction efforts since a failed expansion drive in the late 1990s, and has achieved strong growth outside of France and the United Kingdom. The company reported 10% increase in revenues for 2004 with added 5 million subscribers to their mobile phone network Orange. They also saw increased take-up of broadband telecom services, leading to a 5.5% rise in profits. In addition, France Telecom is planning on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant and will fund it through the sale of shares in PagesJaunes."
orca-mini:3b: France Telecom's mobile phone network Orange enjoyed strong growth in subscribers, leading to a 10% increase in revenues and a 5.5% rise in profits. The firm spent $23.4 billion on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant and plans to meet its financial objectives of growing individual businesses and reducing debt. Its broadband customers also increased, rising to five million across Europe by the end of the year. Looking ahead, France Telecom forecast like-for-like sales growth between 3% and 5%. It consolidates its interest in Equant, which provides telecoms and data services to businesses, by buying out minority shareholders. The deal will be funded by selling an 8% stake in telephone directory company PagesJaunes.
hermes3:3b: France Telecom's Orange subsidiary reports 10% revenue increase to 18.3bn euros due to mobile phone & broadband subscriptions growth (5.5% overall profit), met strategic objectives, reduced debt from 72bn to 43.9bn euros, projects 3-5% like-for-like sales growth over next 3 years.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: France Telecom's profits got a boost from Orange's strong growth in mobile phone subscriptions, which led to a 10% increase in revenues. France Telecom also saw a rise in its broadband customers, and it is spending $578 million on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant. The company's full-year sales rose 2.2%, and it anticipates like-for-like sales growth of 3%-5% over the next three years.
chatgpt-4o-latest: France Telecom's profits rose by 5.5% to 18.3bn euros in 2004, driven by strong growth in mobile subscriptions to Orange and increased broadband adoption. Orange added over five million new customers, boosting its revenues by 10%, while France Telecom's broadband subscribers grew to 5.1 million across Europe. The company reduced its debt from 72bn euros in 2002 to 43.9bn euros and met key strategic goals. It plans to buy out minority shareholders in Equant for 578m euros, funding the deal by selling an 8% stake in PagesJaunes. France Telecom forecasts 3%-5% annual sales growth over the next three years.
stablelm2:1.6b: France Telecom's strong growth in subscriptions for mobile phone network Orange contributed to a 2.2% increase in its revenues and helped boost profits, reaching a 5.5% rise to €1.3bn ($1.4bn; £££). France Telecom plans to spend €m on acquiring minority shareholders in data services provider Equant. CEO Thierry Breton expressed confidence that the company will improve its financial structure while continuing innovation. The company forecasts like-for-like sales growth of between 3% and 5% over the next three years, focusing on expanding its businesses.
granite3.1-dense:2b: France Telecom's mobile subsidiary, Orange, experienced robust growth in 2004, adding over five million new customers and boosting revenues by 10%. This expansion, both domestically in France and the UK and internationally, contributed to a 5.5% rise in France Telecom's overall profits, totaling 18.3bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn). The company met its strategic objectives of business growth and debt reduction; it had reduced its debt from 72bn euros in 2002 to 43.9bn euros by the end of 2004. CEO Thierry Breton highlighted these achievements, stating they improved financial structure while fostering innovation. France Telecom forecasts like-for-like sales growth between 3% and 5% over the next three years. The company plans to acquire Equant's remaining shares by selling an 8% stake in PagesJaunes.
reference: France Telecom, one of the world's largest telecoms and internet service providers, saw its full-year sales rise 2.2% to 47.2bn euros in 2004.Increased take-up of broadband telecoms services also boosted France Telecom's profits, which showed a 5.5% rise to 18.3bn euros ($23.4bn; £12.5bn).France Telecom is to spend 578m euros on buying out minority shareholders in data services provider Equant.France Telecom is consolidating its interest in Equant, which provides telecoms and data services to businesses.An ill-fated expansion drive in the late 1990s saw France Telecom's debt soar to 72bn euros by 2002.Strong growth in subscriptions to mobile phone network Orange has helped boost profits at owner France Telecom.
